pages.text: Labrador Retrievers have two genes that affect how they look. These are the B Locus and E Locus. The B Locus determines whether the dog has black or chocolate fur, while the E Locus determines if the dog has yellow fur or not.

The B Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'B' and the recessive 'b'. The 'B' allele creates black fur, while the 'b' allele creates chocolate fur. Dogs with one copy of 'b' will carry the chocolate trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for chocolate pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'b' will always create either chocolate carriers or chocolate puppies.
pages.title: B Locus

pages.text: The E Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'E' and the recessive 'e'. The 'E' allele allows the B Locus to show, while the 'e' allele overrides it to create yellow fur. Dogs with one copy of 'e' will carry the yellow trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for yellow pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'e' will always create either yellow carriers or yellow puppies.
pages.title: E Locus
